Class SkipListImpl<T extends java.lang.Comparable<? super T>>

  • java.lang.Object
    • SkipListImpl<T>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    SkipList<T>

    public class SkipListImpl<T extends java.lang.Comparable<? super T>>
extends java.lang.Object
implements SkipList<T>

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      private class  SkipListImpl.Contains<V extends java.lang.Comparable<? super V>>
      This class lists the values that are returned when a search function is called It returns the Node, whose value we are searching and the the list of all the Nodes at which the level is descended
      private class  SkipListImpl.Node<E extends java.lang.Comparable<? super E>>
      This class defines the data that a Skip List holds.
      private class  SkipListImpl.RebuildReturns<P extends java.lang.Comparable<? super P>> 
      private class  SkipListImpl.skipListIterator
      This class implements the Iterator interface to traverse the Skip List

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      SkipListImpl()
      This function initializes the head and tail pointers of the Skip List Sets the maximum level equal to the value of (log 100)[Base 2].

      Prints the Skip List Each Node prints the value it holds and the data of the nodes it points to
      void rebuild()
      Idea: In the first iteration, get the reference to your immediate node Declare the # of levels of each node to be equal to log n Set your next[0] to your next node From second iteration, you are called

    • Constructor Detail

      • SkipListImpl

        public SkipListImpl()
        This function initializes the head and tail pointers of the Skip List Sets the maximum level equal to the value of (log 100)[Base 2]. Maximum Level of the Skip List is dynamically increased with the growing size

    • Method Detail

      • updateSize

        private void updateSize(java.lang.String update)
        This function either increases/decreases the size of the Skip List
        Parameters:
        update - - Valid values for this argument are "increase" (increases size by 1) and "decreases" (decreases size by 1)

      • add

        public void add(T x)
        Description copied from interface: SkipList
        Add an element of type T to the Skip List
        Specified by:
        add in interface SkipList<T extends java.lang.Comparable<? super T>>
        Parameters:
        x - - Add this element to Skip List

      • increaseLevel

        private void increaseLevel()
        This method increases the maximum level a new node can take. 1. Increases the current maximum level by 1 2. Create a new Next[] arrays for head and tail with # of levels = currentMaxLevel + 1 3. Copy the content from old next array of head to the new next array head

      • updateWidths

        private void updateWidths(SkipListImpl.Node<T> newNode,
                          SkipListImpl.Contains<T> c)
        This method updates the width of all the links affected by the insertion of newNode Assume you are adding node 'B' after 'A' (to write comments with an example)
        Parameters:
        newNode - - Newly added node
        c - - Returned by the search(newNode.data)

      • choice

        private int choice()
        This function chooses a random level that a new node can take. Level is equal to the number of 1's generated before first 0
        Returns:
        - Level chooses randomly

      • ceiling

        public T ceiling(T x)
        Description copied from interface: SkipList
        This functions finds the ceiling of a given number in a Skip List
        Specified by:
        ceiling in interface SkipList<T extends java.lang.Comparable<? super T>>
        Parameters:
        x - - Element whose ceiling value has to be found
        Returns:
        - Returns an element Y where Y is the smallest element that is greater than or equal to x. Otherwise, it returns null

      • getNextNode

        private void getNextNode(SkipListImpl.Node<T> from,
                         int level)
        This function returns the next node that has to be pointed by the node 'from' during rebuild Typically this node is two leaps away from its below level
        Parameters:
        from - - Node from where we should find the next node
        level - - The level of the next pointer which has to be set

      • rebuild

        public void rebuild()
        Idea: In the first iteration, get the reference to your immediate node Declare the # of levels of each node to be equal to log n Set your next[0] to your next node From second iteration, you are called
        Specified by:
        rebuild in interface SkipList<T extends java.lang.Comparable<? super T>>

      • findIndex_LinearSearch

        public T findIndex_LinearSearch(int index)
        This function finds the element at a given index This function is designed to highlight the efficiency of the Skip Lists
        Parameters:
        index - - The index position of the Skip List
        Returns:
        - Element present at Index. If index is lesser than size, this returns null
